div1.p: Lazear writes that he misses watching his son grow and the comforts of home.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, May 6 1900
div1.p:
Your letter of Apr. 26 reached
me several days ago. There is not
much for me to put into a letter here.

One day is like another. I am kept
busy with my regular duties and my
own work. I have not heard
from Mabel since she left Baltimore.
A letter I got yesterday said they would
start the next day. Little Houston has
done a good deal of travelling for one
of his age. He seems to enjoy it
however. He will have grown a good
deal before I see him. I hate to
miss any of his childhood. It is
interesting to see him growing and developing
from day to day. As to his forgetting
me, a child of that age forgets one
gives as much in a week as in six
months.

One misses the good concerts here. There
are two bands, one of which is a very
good one and plays classical music
but a band at the best leaves much
lacking. They play every morning
and almost every evening but the
headquarters are quite a way off
and I hardly ever go over at night
unless it is moonlight. There is
a dance every Saturday night which
every people come out from Havana
for.

The drill ground for the cavalry and
artillery is in plain ve from here.
They however drill only early in the
morning on account of the danger
of hard work in the Lupin se

I know you are enjoying Windsor
now, this is one of the best times
of year there, before hot weather
begins.
